question: Is it true milk used to be delivered to your house every morning?

answers.answer: No, not every morning. There was a route, like a mailman, but usually, you got enough to last a few days or a week. Most people didn't have room for more than a little bit, because refrigerators (and before that, ice boxes) were fairly small.

When we went to our house in Connecticut for the summer it was. Don’t remember if it was every single day. Might have been. But there was an aluminum box outside the front door and the milk truck came and the driver put the glass milk bottles in it and then when you were finished you put the empty glass bottles back in the aluminum box and he picked them up and put more milk in there. To be honest I completely forgot about that until you asked this question. That was like in the late 1950s into the ‘60s or something when I was a little kid. Seems kind of weird now. But there were others weird things going on like when you went to get gas they always pumped it, no self service and they always checked your oil and washed your windshield. Every single time. And I remember being in my early teens and being able to go and buy cigarettes they didn’t ID you or anything. And when you went to the supermarket you bought your food but they bagged it and put it a little conveyor belt system that went from inside the store to the outside and you pulled your car up and there was a guy there to take your bags out of the bin and put them in the trunk of your car or in your backseat or whatever. They were just ‘weird’ things going on. You interacted more with people actually. I think people basically trusted one another more also
comments: Yep.

answers.answer: Yes it's true. Milk and eggs. Also had the Omar Man deliver pastries.

Yes, milk and butter were delivered every day.  There were also egg and produce deliveries on a regular basis.

question: Did USA help UK during world war II from the beginning?
details: They helped after pearl harbour was bombed

answers.answer: They helped after pearl harbour was bombed

No. England begged for supplies, war machines and planes, arms and assistance but the people and Congress were not willing to jump into the conflict. Roosevelt kept trying to get them to see reason, but he himself wasn't willing to send Americans to another war in Europe--he was really reluctant to do so, and there were many conflicts to be addressed at home--race riots, and labor union revolts for two. FDR was finally able to get an aid package passed that sent bombers and arms to England but it wasn't until the attack on Pearl Harbor that the American people and government changed their minds about participation. And it was almost too late. By the time America joined the war, Hitler had already invaded most of Europe and Northern Africa, and the Japanese had begun to conquer the South Pacific. It was a very close contest for a while.

answers.answer: Only with great difficulty.  They would recognize automobiles, but wouldn't know how to start or drive a modern one.  They would maybe recognize landline telephones, but wouldn't know how to use one and wouldn't have a clue about cell phones.  They wouldn't know anything about computers or the internet.  They would know a bit about radio, but wouldn't know anything radio broadcasts or about television.  They would know about banks but not about credit or debit cards.  They would be shocked by modern styles of clothing, particularly summer wear.  They would know about aviation, but almost certainly had never been up in an airplane.  They would be surprised that passenger railroads were no longer heavily used.  If from a city, they would be surprised that most streetcars lines were long ago abandoned, but they would more or less recognize the subway.
I think they could, but not right away.  It might take a year or two to learn modern slang, and computer skills, and get used to fast food and sound movies.

question: What age group is the book "Animal Farm" aimed at?

It's a fable about political revolution.  The downtrodden animals oust the tyrant farmer, but everyone is not free and equal in the farmyard.

question: Do you believe that we inherit memories from our ancestors?

question: whats a good way to start an acting career after graduating high school?

DNA research has confirmed what was believed before was that that the indigenous peoples of the Americas are descended from a group of people who crossed a land connection between Asia and North America sometime during the Last Glacial Maximum (26,500 to 19,000 years before present, or YBP).

A little over 11,000 years ago, a grieving family in Central Alaska laid to rest a six-week-old baby girl, a three-year-old child, and a preterm female fetus. According to their custom, the children were interred under a hearth inside their home and provisioned with the carefully crafted stone points and bone foreshafts of hunting lances. question: Did anyone ever find out the purpose of pyramids ?

answers.answer: Triangles are the strongest shape, so pyramids are a natural choice for a sturdy monument. There's a reason they're the only remaining Wonder of the Ancient World!

They're tombs. It's that simple. Ancient Egypt is plenty fascinating enough already to not have to look for mysteries and conspiracies where none are. The Old/Middle Kingdom tombs have been robbed since ancient Egyptian times. In the late Ramesside period a lot of royal tombs were dug up and reburied in less conspicuous sites like the KV.
Some people believe the pyramids were built under the supervision of aliens as power generators.

The first Egyptian tombs were mastabas, rectangular brick structures where kings and nobles were entombed. Each of them contained a subterranean burial chamber and a separate, above ground chapel for mortuary rituals. In the Old Kingdom the mastaba developed into the pyramid, which symbolized the primeval mound of Egyptian myth. Pyramids were reserved for royalty, and were accompanied by large mortuary temples sitting at their base. Middle Kingdom pharaohs continued to build pyramids, but the popularity of mastabas waned. Increasingly, commoners with sufficient means were buried in rock-cut tombs with separate mortuary chapels nearby, an approach which was less vulnerable to tomb robbery. By the beginning of the New Kingdom even the pharaohs were buried in such tombs, and they continued to be used until the decline of the religion itself.

Simple answer: grave robbery.  A lot of tombs had been robbed during and before the time when the British took interest in Egyptian mummies.  In fact they had found so many mummies that they sometimes ground them up and used the powder as medicine.
Yes they did. The book, The Purpose of Pyramids, was published by the Pelican Press in 1971.

question: How can a photographer move forward in his hobby when he is already taking very high quality photos?

It's going to be difficult to know where your opportunities for improvement are unless you have your work critically critiqued.  Sign up for a workshop and have your work critiqued.  Of course, the workshop isn't free, but the cost (especially with a world renowned photographer) will be worth the price of admission.  Just be careful because there are a lot of mediocre photographers trying to make a buck by doing workshops.

Some of my most successful photos were taken with a lowly Holga "toy" camera and even a pinhole camera. They were successful because the photos made a statement and represented a theme. So, start having a REASON to take a series of photos. Shoot to create EMOTION, not just "high quality".

answers.answer: Well actually his support declined starting 1932 since the economy of Germany was improving and hence the German workers did not need to turn to a radical like him. However his party still held enough seats in the Reichstag in early 1933, and the Conservatives wanted to use him against the Socialists/Communists and other Leftists hence why prominent Conservative leaders persuaded president Hindenburg to appoint him as chancellor..  Conservative thought they could "control" Hitler and his party..   we know how that turned out!
the 1933 elections he only got 43% of the Vote and Bribed the Presidents advisers and Hitler was appointed, Chancellor

Initially they didn't.  The most support the Nazis ever got in the free parliamentary elections held before the Reichstag Fire was 37%.  The Nazis were the largest party in the Reichstag, but actually lost seats in the late 1932 election and had to form a coalition government with other conservative parties.  Hitler only managed to really take over after the Reichstag Fire, when a mentally ill Dutch Communist set fire to the German parliamentary building.  He and the Nazis used this as an excuse to pass a law granting Hitler, as Chancellor, a slew of emergency powers which he effectively used to end free government in Germany.  It's difficult to measure public approval in a dictatorship, but the Nazis did seem genuinely popular for much of the 1930s, right up until probably 1941 or so.  And it was because the Nazis seemed to be delivering on their promises to "make Germany great again".  The economy, which had already been improving in the last years of the Weimar Republic, continued to improve.  Germany experienced a relatively mild depression compared to many of the other major world powers.  The Nazis were also popular because they oversaw a rebuilding of German prestige in the 1930s.  They rebuilt the German military and acted to get back territory which had been lost after WWI, like Alsace-Lorraine and the Rhineland.  They also built on decades old nationalist dreams of uniting all Germans under one state through things such as the annexation of Austria and later on the Sudetenland in Czechoslovakia.  When WWII started, Germans were initially wary but soon became overjoyed.  The conquest of Poland was easy.  But even more importantly, for Nazi popularity, so was the war in France.  In WWI the Germans had spent four years trying, and failing, to move a few miles in France.  Under the Nazis they defeated the combined French and British forces in a month!  If you were a patriotic Germany, one who didn't care about things like political freedom or the persecution of the Jews, then this was amazing.  The Nazis would have seemed to have the secret formula for putting Germany back in its rightful, in their eyes, place in the sun.
The German people were starving, unemployed, and homeless and the Versailles Treaty was holding their heads underwater, figuratively speaking.

Hitler was very popular but the majority of Germans never supported him unless you count after he came to power and there was no choice. During the Presidential elections of 1932 he received 30% in the first round and 36% in the runoff. After Hitler's appointment as Chancellor he called for new elections where the Nazis got 43% of the vote.  In November 1933 Parliamentary elections in Germany took place  They were the first since the Nazi Party seized complete power with the passage of the Enabling Act in March. All opposition parties had been banned by this time, and voters were presented with a single list containing Nazis and 22 non-party "guests" of the Nazi Party The Nazis got 92% of the vote. As and aside the Nazi Party at its largest had 8million member or about 10% of the population.

question: photography, a sigma 17-70mm 2.8-4.0clens I ordered makes a horrid loose rattle when handled, anyone explain to me the reason for this?
details: You may have turned the camera off or disconnected the lens while the optical image stabilizer was still active. In this cases the lens might rattle when shaken.

answers.answer: You may have turned the camera off or disconnected the lens while the optical image stabilizer was still active. In this cases the lens might rattle when shaken.
Some lenses rattle when shaken, not stirred, which may the the vibration reduction mechanism. You would need to compare this to another lens.

Something may be broken or loose inside the lens. Return it for a refund or get another one of the same model. Late Popular Photography and Modern Photography magazine editor Herbert Kepler once wrote a tutorial on shopping for used lenses. He told the readers to shake the lens gently to see if there is a rattling noise inside before buying. If a lens has been dropped or banged around, something may break inside and that piece of loose material will make a rattling sound when the lens is shaken.

All lenses make a sound when autofocusing. The trouble is you're bothered by it. You can return it to the store, with the box and the sales receipt, and have them see if it's an actual problem. While there, ask them to test another same-model lens with your camera and compare if it rattles as loudly as yours. Warranty allows you to get a free replacement within a week from purchase if proven it's a factory defect.

You've probably ordered the "Rattling" version by mistake. Unlike the non-Rattling version which, presumably, you were really wanting, the Rattling version rattles when being handled to provide a pleasant "rattling" sound to the owner when it's being handled. Many options are open to you if you want to sort this problem out. My suggestion is you either (a) just don't listen to it, or (b) handle it as little as possible. Hope this helped.
There could be a loose bit rattling about inside but you'd see it in the pictures. I assume you'd mention if you could see anything. But if there was a loose bit you'd see it sometimes.

question: Is “declaration of war” an antiquated expression?
details: The last official declaration of war was in 1945 (Soviet Union on Japan) since then there has never been a country declaring war on another.

answers.answer: Not according to Wiki there have been a few " Declarations of War" since.

For all practical purposes, yes.  Member states of the United Nations (which includes most of the nations of the world) are limited in their ability to engage in war, hence there is little, if any, need to declare war.  Matters generally must be presented to the UN Security Council (with excepts for regional alliances and self-defense measures).  Also, by not declaring war, a nation avoids restrictions that would apply under the rules of international law.  For example, if Maggie Thatcher had declared war against Argentina during the Falklands War, her buddy, Ronnie Reagan, could not have provided aid, because the United States, remaining neutral, could not have provided aid to a belligerent nation.

question: want to be actor? advice ?
details: Can someone give me advice on how to be an actor at the age of 16? - how to balance it with school and outside classes because I’ve read that you need experience outside of school. What are good alongside jobs that fit with wanting to be a professional actor?

answers.answer: There are community theaters and summer stock and school plays all of which can provide much needed experience. You also might try mimicking foreign accents or regional accents as good actors can do this and are sometimes called to do so in both plays and movies. Also study interesting characters whom you meet in your own life and try to play them on your own. Now that there are easy to access recording devices on computers and even smartphones you can make videos of yourself and see how you are doing. When you watch movies or go to plays evaluate the acting on not only how good it is but on what techniques the actor is using such things as emoting or a stage whisper. Note where the emphasis is placed in the pronunciation of words. When I was in Brisbane Australia I noticed that the accent was often placed on the last syllable of a word and that the voice went up in tone like they were asking a question which is one of the ways you can distinguish an Australian accent from a British accent. Some interesting American accents would be a Southern drawl, a Western Twang, a New England or Boston accent which became noticed when JFK was president in which r's were added to a word ending in a such as Cuba was pronounced Cuber.and r's were dropped in other words such as park is pronounced pack. Then are expressions such as in Maine they often say ayup, and in the South y'all come. Also study actors who had classical training such as Richard Burton who has a Shakespearean ring to his voice which makes for a very powerful delivery. There there is method acting like Marlon Brando.

question: Why did BBC say HIV was transmitted to humans first in Africa in the 1920s? I thought it started in San Francisco in the 1980s?
details: It first became widely known about in the West in the early 1980s. Obviously it must have been around for a while before then.

answers.answer: It first became widely known about in the West in the early 1980s. Obviously it must have been around for a while before then.

HIV crossed from chimps to humans in the 1920s in what is now the Democratic Republic of Congo. This was probably as a result of chimps carrying the Simian Immunodeficiency Virus (SIV), a virus closely related to HIV, being hunted and eaten by people living in the area.

No.  It comes from Africa.  It was a gay flight attendant on Air Canada that brought it too the Americas, but, t began in Africa, where it is not a gay disease at all.  It likely crossed over from apes, mainly by eating them.

HIV/AIDS only became first identified medically in the very early 80s.  But the virus was around long before them.  It originated in Africa with a similar disease among primates called Simian Immunodeficiency Virus.  From genetic testing they can tell about how long it took for the virus to mutate from that to the form of HIV which we have now.  So sometime in the 1920s or 1930s the virus jumped the species barrier between apes and humans.  It's speculated that perhaps someone became infected while butchering an ape for the bushmeat trade.  By the early 1950s, HIV was making its way out of Africa and into the rest of the world.  There are documented cases as early as the late 40s where people died of symptoms which strongly suggest they had AIDS.  In 1968 a teenage boy named Robert Rayford checked himself in to a St Louis area hospital.  He was suffering from a bewildering array of symptoms that his doctors couldn't diagnose or link to a unified cause.  They were so baffled by his disease that when he died a year later they saved tissue samples.  Decades later the samples were tested and Rayford was found to have had HIV, with his symptoms being consistent with what came to be known as AIDS years after his death. Rayford had never traveled outside the American Midwest and told his doctors that he'd been having symptoms for a few years.  So we know that HIV was circulating in America, and far from the enclave of San Francisco, by the mid 1960s at the latest, almost two decades before it would be identified.

They are politically invested in the Gay community and are careful about deflecting criticism or the potential for it in their reporting.  Gays are an important voting block and they do not want to alienate them.

Evidence shows it was probably twenty years earlier than the 1920s. Little was known about human immunodeficiency illnesses before AIDS in the early 1980s. It existed far earlier but doctors who saw cases and documented them didn't know what it was or how to classify it.

Both HIV-1 and HIV-2 are believed to have originated in non-human primates in West-central Africa, and are believed to have transferred to humans (a process known as zoonosis) in the early 20th century. HIV-1 appears to have originated in southern Cameroon from  a simian immunodeficiency virus (SIV) that infects wild chimpanzees The closest relative of HIV-2 is a virus of the sooty mangabey , an Old World monkey living in littoral West Africa (from southern Senegal to western Côte d'Ivoire,   AIDS was first clinically observed in 1981 in the United States The first news story on "an exotic new disease" appeared May 18, 1981 in the gay newspaper New York Native.
Because It has been floating around the jungle for the last 200 years or so, that is where viruses come from.  Jungles in Africa and duck markets in China and places.
It was first identified as a unique illness in the 1980's.  But it was around before that.
Because it is true.

answers.answer: We went places and talked to each other face to face.

I used to talk on the phone for hours in the 70’s. My dad’s friends would tell him: “I tried calling you last nite, but your phone was busy.” Also my friends would hang out at the town square or at a sub shop. Good times.

Before cellphones, we spent lots of times with friends, face-to-face, hanging out. There was no need to share anything to the world. It was actually the complete reverse. What each group of friends did was more elite if the other groups didn't know.

This is going to shock you, but we actually flirted in person, face-to-face. We flirted at dances, parties, bowling alleys, skating rinks, movie theaters, parks, school and just hanging out with friends. Before there were malls, people met downtown at record shops, soda shops, diners or anyplace that had a lunch counter. Or they met at places like McDonalds, where they could talk for hours for the price of a soft drink. Fast food restaurants didn't have nearly as much seating as they do now, but a bunch of people could sit in a car or hang out in the parking lot and nothing would be said as long as they weren't bothering anyone. I find it amazing that young teens today consider themselves as having a girlfriend/boyfriend when all they do is text one another without actually talking on the phone or talking in person.
Books and lego.  Also, each other.  I can still remember Teresa Liberto's entire grade nine wardrobe.

Well Ruby was a big fan of JFK.  He really liked the President and so was presumably angry that Oswald had killed him.  After the shooting, Ruby also said that he wanted to spare Jackie Kennedy from having to testify at a trial for Oswald.  But his shooting may have been impulsive.  Ruby was a police gadfly who was known to a lot of cops.  He had spent the days after Kennedy's assassination hanging around the police station a couple of times.  He doesn't seem to have been intentionally stalking Oswald, or at least not doing so in a very determined manner.  He may have just been trying to get close to a big story which was happening right in his own backyard.  On the day that Oswald was murdered, Ruby took his sweet time getting there.  He stopped off first to wire money to someone at Western Union.  Then, with just a few minutes to spare before Oswald showed up, he casually walked down a ramp into the parking garage.  It may be that when Oswald was brought out, Ruby, who was nicknamed "Sparky" because of his temper, simply got filled with rage and lashed out.

question: How do you write down your thoughts and your feelings?
details: I always want to write down my thoughts, feelings, and emotions but I can't ever seem to express them in words correctly.

answers.answer: Keep a notebook.  Write things down as you think of them and put them together later.

There is an excellent soul-opening book for you, Kenta: Julia Cameron's "The Artist's Way".  However, in the short-term, to begin journaling you might consider using a single word at first---just one word that you can feel or visualize that seems meaningful.  I wrote an exquisite poem that began with seeing a giant eagle in a metal cage at the St. Louis zoo with no room for his wingspan---the sheer sadness I sensed in this eagle stayed with me, so when I went to a Creative Writing class that week at St. Louis University taught by an elderly gay professor named Dr. Montesi, a man who had won awards for his writings and poetry, I was older and had been in the military during the Vietnam war, but none of the younger kids in class had that experience.  They were making fun of the short professor's speaking style and of his poem "Dom Zu Muenster" about a World War II bombing.  I sat in the back of the room and saw the professor standing just outside the door, hearing his students mocking his art and his personality---and he suddenly became that caged eagle with no room for  his full wingspan.  That day, I sat on a bus stop bench and the poem "Hummingbird and Eagle: A Love Story" poured out of me: "The oh so tiny hummingbird I be/Pushed to be an eagle by life's demands on me/Made to see myself with only eagle eyes/Thus lost to me because of my diminished size/Crying to be found but no one hears such tiny cries/And so I fall." 2nd verse: "You the giant eagle with the tethered wings/Held to ground and yet your kingly spirit sings/Crying silent songs that echo through the endless skies/Raging helplessly within to be a bird that flies/Held back by the force of fear each time your spirit tries/You hear my call."  And the poem goes on through two more verses, then ends with two lines: "You saved the hummingbird with hidden courage that broke through/And doing that you saved the mighty eagle that is you."  This masterpiece has gotten standing ovations at all-male prisons or public gatherings, and it began with the vision of a caged eagle, triggered by the sadness on Dr. Montesi's face.

But what should I do so he doesn't get addicted to those books. help? what is the right thing to do?

answers.answer: I suppose you want to be unique, not refered to in the same sentence as your brothers by parents and friends. You like being the only girl and have secrets they can't discover and own.
You admit the book is a good book. I can't imagine why you would want your brother NOT to read a good book.
You don't.  Your brother can read whatever he wants to.

I am the eldest of five - three sisters and a brother. My advice is to let it go. It's not for you to dictate what your siblings can or cannot enjoy. Boys are naturally curious about girls. I wasn't above reading a bit of Nancy Drew or The Babysitter's Club when I was a young kid, and I did that in an effort to sate my curiosity, not because I secretly liked reading books about girls. In later years I would find that the works of several female writers had a massive effect on me and my perception of the world - Jane Austen, George Eliot, Flannery O'Connor, Dorothy Parker, Mary Shelley... I'm not sure I can say that reading their books taught me much about women - growing up with three sisters you would think I'd know a lot more than I do and having been married for so many years and having daughters of my own it would make sense that I'd be considered an expert on women, but alas, that's probably why I've spent such a massive chunk of my life reading because half the time I really don't have any idea what the Hell they're on about or doing or thinking at all. Let your brother alone. Even if you'd written the book yourself you wouldn't reserve the right to tell him he can't read it, and I might not know women very well, but I certainly know how blokes tick - if you show him that reading your books gets your goat, it'll only serve to spur the lad on to read the lot of them.
Have you tried sleeping with your brothers?

question: What was the conflict between Germany and the Soviet Union during World War II?
details: Well, the fact that germany invaded the ussr was probably a dealbreaker as far as peace was concerned.

answers.answer: Well, the fact that germany invaded the ussr was probably a dealbreaker as far as peace was concerned.
Hitler launched Operation Barbarossa, the largest grand invasion in the history of the world.

On  22 June 1941, with the Operation Barbarossa offensive  a conflict started between Germans and Russians. The main players involved in this war were the Nazi Germany, its allies and Finland on one side, against the Soviet Union and its allies on the other side. The conflict began with the , when Axis forces crossed the borders described in the German–Soviet Nonaggression Pact, thereby invading the Soviet Union. It has been known as the Great Patriotic War in the Soviet Union and its successor states. In Germany it was called the Eastern Front or the German-Soviet War by outside parties. The United States and the United Kingdom both provided substantial material aid to the Soviet Union. The fomenting cause of this war was the fact that both Germany and the Soviet Union remained unsatisfied with the outcome of World War I (1914–1918). Russians had ceded lot of of their land  territory to German. Germany in its turn surrendered to the Allies (November 1918) and these territories were liberated under the terms of the Paris Peace Conference of 1919 at Versailles. At this time Soviet Union was in the midst of Civil war and so were no9t a party to the negotiations about these land territories.

Germany and Soviets made a pact not to attack each other.  Midway through the war, Hitler violated the pact, attacked Russia, and killed many people.  In the end, Russia conquered Berlin as Hitler committed suicide in his bunker nearby.

Russia was largely responsible for World War I. Russia and Russians were on Adolf Hitler's sh-t list for humiliating Germany in World War I. That's not my opinion. Adolf Hitler said so. He said so in Mein Kampf, calling Russians "sub-human" and said they were to be "cleansed" from the Earth.

question: Has France Ever Apologized for Its Role in the Khodynka Field Tragedy?
details: On May 30, 1896, four days after the coronation of Tsar Nicholas II, a celebration was planned at the Khodynka Field, near Moscow.  By 6:00 a.m. that morning, about 500,000 people were present.  Each person was to receive a gift from the Tsar --  a bag containing a bread roll, sausage, pretzels, gingerbread, and a commemorative cup.  Beer was also available.  A rumor began to circulate that there would not be enough beer and pretzels for everyone, but that the commemorative cup contained a gold coin.  A stampede ensued, and nearly 1,400 people were trampled to death.
